span.a: A Day at Summer School Information
You are currently on this page - COVID-19 Updates

td.p: Click on this link to find the lesson plans by grade level K-8 and subject area 9-12.

p.a: Extended Safer at Home Order - April 17, 2020

hr.p: Principal Letter to Parents on Virtual Learning - March 25, 2020

td.p: In compliance with the Governor’s order, Mayville School District facilities are closed until further notice.
All district staff are currently working remotely. Please be safe during this unprecedented time. We look forward to reopening our schools for our students and staff soon!

p.b: In compliance with the statewide school closure, the School District of Mayville will implement the following schedule:
March 23-27: School Cancellation (Five (5) days originally built in the schedule to address inclement weather)

Our District plan provides virtual instruction for students that satisfies DPI and CDC requirements and prevents extending the school year. Our buildings will remain open for staff use. Our District staff will be communicating their expectations for March 30th and beyond with Virtual Learning Time by the end of the day on Wednesday, March 25, 2020.

meta.p: The Mayville School District is on Spring Break Monday, March 16th through Friday, March 20th. According to a state-wide mandate issued by Governor Evers, all Wisconsin Schools will be closed indefinitely. Click here to reference the most recent district communication regarding next steps for Mayville learners and families. Updates will continue to be communicated to district families directly and will continue to be posted here.

td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

td.p: Gov. Tony Evers on March 13, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain the spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin.

The shutdown will begin Wednesday March 18 and run through April 5, though it could be extended, Evers' office said in a statement. On March 17th, Evers updated the mandate to close schools indefinitely or until further notice based on the spread of the virus.

“Closing our schools is not a decision I made lightly, but keeping our kids, our educators, our families, and our communities safe is a top priority as we continue our work to respond to and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin,” Evers said. “Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care. We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”
The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state,

Mayville School District will work to ensure learning continues for students. Please continue to check back here for additional updates, and watch for direct communication from your student(s)' building leadership and teacher(s).

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div:
We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in the Mayville School District.
We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurse and the Dodge County Health Department, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin. The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact the school to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: Mayville School District has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.
td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.

td.p: This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic, the President and Governor declaring it a public health emergency and the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13 on all travel from Europe to the U.S.
td.div: The state of Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS) is asking schools and organizations to:

ul.li: Avoid traveling to areas in the US with sustained community transmission of COVID-19 (currently Washington, New York, and California). See map of US sustained community transmission of COVID-19.
Self-quarantine for 14 days upon return for anyone who travels to any U.S. states with confirmed community spread of COVID-19.

td.p: Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country with a Level 3 travel health notice, please contact Mayville School District before returning to school. The CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days. Read more about travel on the CDC's website.

We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students’ safety first. If you have any questions, reach out to Scott Sabol, District Administrator at ssabol@mayville.k12.wi.us or at 920-387-7963.
